seoContent.heading: Experience the Next Generation of Chess Variants
seoContent.text: Join the chessperiment community and play unique chess variants online with friends or against our integrated Stockfish AI. Our platform allows you to use custom boards and piece sets designed by creators around the world. Whether you're interested in testing a new piece logic you just created or want to jump into a match with standard rules on an irregular board, our smooth multiplayer experience has you covered. Start a private match by sharing a room code, or join the lobby to find other players. With real-time move validation and advanced engine analysis, chessperiment offers a robust environment for both casual play and competitive testing of new game mechanics.

EditorBoard.title: Chess Board Editor - Design Custom Boards
EditorBoard.description: Create your own chess board layouts. Customize dimensions, colors, and starting positions. Export or play directly.

seoContent.heading: Create and Share Custom Chess Boards
seoContent.text: With the chessperiment Chess Board Editor, you can easily design custom 8x8, 10x10, or any irregular board sizes. Customize colors, create complex starting positions, and share your creations with the world. Whether you are building a classic chess variant, exploring fairy chess concepts, or designing creative chess puzzles, our grid-based editor provides the flexibility you need. Define playable areas, block squares to create obstacles, and test your new game mechanics instantly in your browser. Our platform supports advanced board configurations that go beyond the standard grid, allowing for truly unique strategic battlefields.

EditorPiece.title: Pixel Chess Piece Editor | Create Custom Pieces | chessperiment
EditorPiece.description: Design your own chess pieces with our pixel art editor. Create unique kings, queens, and custom fairy pieces.

seoContent.heading: Design and Logic for Custom Chess Pieces
seoContent.text: The chessperiment Piece Editor is a comprehensive tool for creating unique chess pieces from scratch. Use our 64x64 pixel art canvas to design the visual representation of your piece, and then use our intuitive move editor to define its strategic capabilities. You can create sliding pieces, leapers, or even complex pieces with move-dependent logic. Our platform allows you to specify exactly how a piece moves, captures, and interacts with other elements on the board. Whether you are recreating historical chess variants or inventing something entirely new, the Piece Editor provides the technical precision required for high-level game design. Save your creations in sets and import them into any board configuration for immediate play.

Marketplace.title: chessperiment Marketplace | Download Custom Chess Sets
Marketplace.description: Browse and download community-created chess boards and piece sets. Enhance your game with unique designs.

seoContent.heading: Discover and Share Custom Chess Assets
seoContent.text: The chessperiment Marketplace is the central hub for our creative community. Explore a vast collection of custom chess boards, pixel-perfect piece sets, and unique board designs shared by users worldwide. Whether you are looking for a minimalist aesthetic or a complex medieval theme, our marketplace offers a wide variety of assets to customize your chess experience. You can browse through free sets or discover premium content crafted by expert designers. Every item in the marketplace can be easily integrated into your library and used in your games. Share your own creations to build your reputation as a chess variant designer and contribute to the growing ecosystem of custom board games.

PieceEditorFAQ.description: Everything you need to know about creating custom pieces with complex logic.

general.title: General Concepts
general.a1: The Piece Editor allows you to design the visual appearance and the movement logic of your custom chess pieces. It consists of a Pixel Editor (64x64) and two logic editors: the Visual Move Editor for geometric constraints and the Visual Logic Editor (Block Editor) for event-driven behavior.
general.a2: Instead of fixed patterns, the engine uses geometric vectors. A move is defined by its displacement in X (horizontal) and Y (vertical) directions. This allows for flexible definitions like 'any distance on the diagonal' or 'exactly 2 squares horizontally'.

moveEditor.title: Visual Move Editor
moveEditor.q1: How do I define basic movement?
moveEditor.a1: You define rules using variables: diffX (horizontal step), diffY (vertical step), absDiffX (absolute horizontal distance), and absDiffY (absolute vertical distance). If a move matches your conditions, it is marked as 'Allow' (legal) or 'Disallow' (illegal).
moveEditor.q2: What is the difference between sliding and jumping?
moveEditor.a2: Currently, custom moves are 'Teleport' based by default. If you define a rule for a target square, the piece jumps there. Future updates will introduce 'Collision' properties to toggle sliding behavior (where intermediate squares must be empty).

logicEditor.title: Visual Logic Editor (Block Editor)
logicEditor.a1: Triggers are the starting points of your logic chains (e.g., 'onCapture', 'onMove', 'onCaptured'). They fire when a specific event occurs. You must snap Effect blocks to these Triggers to make them execute.
logicEditor.a2: The 'Prevent Default' block is a powerful terminal that stops the engine from performing its standard action. For example, placing it inside 'onCaptured' makes the piece invincible because the capture event is canceled.
logicEditor.a3: Yes. Using the 'Transformation' block, you can turn a piece into another type. This is commonly used for pawn promotion or special 'Phoenix' pieces that transform instead of dying.
logicEditor.a4: You can use the 'Modify Var' block to increment or decrement numeric values (like 'Health' or 'Rage stacks'). You can then use the 'onVar' trigger to react when a variable reaches a certain threshold.

troubleshooting.title: Troubleshooting
troubleshooting.a1: Ensure that your blocks are physically snapped together. Floating blocks will not execute. Also, check the trigger context: 'onCapture' fires *during* the capture, while 'onMove' fires *after* the board has already updated.
troubleshooting.a2: No. 'onThreat' is a passive check used for highlighting. You cannot 'prevent' a threat; you can only prevent the move or capture that causes it.
